awd_titl_txt: Modeling and Analysis of Liquid Sloshing and Its Effects on Vehicle Stability
awd_abstract_narration:
Liquid sloshing has a significant impact on the dynamics and stability of highway, rail, marine, and space transportation systems. Nonetheless, because of the lack of computational algorithms and high fidelity models necessary to develop the knowledge and better understanding of the sloshing effect on vehicle dynamics and stability, transportation of hazardous materials has resulted in deadly, costly, and environmentally damaging accidents. Liquid can produce significant forces as the results of the interaction with containers and/or tank cars mounted on trucks, aircraft, railroad vehicles, missiles, rockets, offshore structures, and marine applications among many others. Existing simple liquid sloshing approaches commonly used are not designed for complex motion scenarios. While the use of computational algorithms is necessary to predict the response of detailed vehicle models, there is no in existence today an efficient and accurate continuum-based liquid sloshing approach to quantify the sloshing effect which can be significant during curve negotiations, rapid lane changes, and acceleration and braking scenarios. This award supports fundamental research to develop the first generation of liquid sloshing computational algorithms for modeling complex motion scenarios, developing safety guidelines, and accurate accident reconstructions. In particular, hazardous material accidents, which result in significant economic loss, environmental contamination, loss of lives, and property damage, can be avoided or significantly reduced through better understanding of the effect of sloshing on highway, rail, marine, and space transportation systems. This project will also lead to the development of new knowledge, approaches, and tools that can be used in the education of senior undergraduate and graduate students at University of Illinois at Chicago which is designated as a minority serving institution. 

The use of efficient continuum-based liquid sloshing models that capture the liquid distributed inertia and viscosity can overcome the limitations of existing liquid sloshing models. To this end, new liquid sloshing models will be developed and integrated with multibody system (MBS) algorithms that allow for developing and solving the differential/algebraic equations of vehicle models that include significant details. In order to achieve efficient integration of liquid sloshing/MBS algorithms and avoid the difficulties of integrating existing Eulerian-based fluid formulations with the Lagrangian-based MBS algorithms, new total-Lagrangian non-incremental liquid sloshing solution procedures will be introduced. Three different liquid sloshing approaches will be developed; the finite element (FE) absolute nodal coordinate formulation (ANCF) will be used to develop high fidelity MBS models, the floating frame of reference (FFR) formulation will be used to develop low-order MBS models, and the smoothed particle hydrodynamics (SPH) method will be used to develop a different model to assess the effect of the liquid turbulence on vehicle dynamics. The Lagrangian approaches will allow for accurately capturing the effect of the fluid inertia in complex vehicle motion scenarios.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: SENSORS AND SENSOR SYSTEMS FOR CIS

por.por_cntn:
New low- and high-fidelity liquid sloshing computational formulations and algorithms were developed in this research. Nonlinear continuum-based formulations were used with a total Lagrangian approach to study effect of liquid sloshing oscillations on highway and railroad vehicle dynamics and stability. The approaches developed allow using general fluid constitutive models including crude oil constitutive models that characterize different oil types, classified as light, medium, and heavy, depending on the oil viscosity. Evaluation of effect of crude oil rheological properties on centrifugal forces during curve negotiation showed increase in crude oil density is responsible for exacerbating train lateral instability effects, thus the risk of vehicle roll-over. Liquid sloshing solutions obtained using the finite element absolute nodal coordinate formulation (ANCF) were verified using benchmark problems. While the results were found to be in good agreement with results of other numerical methods, it was found that number of degrees of freedom required for ANCF convergence is around one order of magnitude less than what is required by other existing methods; and in some problems, the ANCF model requires nearly 40 times fewer degrees of freedom than other existing particle-based methods.  

A new class of finite elements that can be used in developing low-fidelity liquid sloshing models was introduced. The new ANCF/FFR elements have the following important features: complex curved geometries can be captured eliminating the tedious work required for converting solid models to analysis meshes; same number of nodal coordinates as conventional elements is used; no distinction is made between plate and shell geometries; no changes need to be made in the main solvers since only preprocessing changes are required; nonlinear continuum mechanics and material models can be systematically used; and a local linear problem can be created to eliminate insignificant deformation modes.

  A new objective large rotation and large deformation viscoelastic constitutive model defined by the Navier–Stokes equations was proposed for ANCF solids. To improve computational efficiency for detailed vehicle models, the two-loop implicit sparse matrix numerical integration (TLISMNI) method was enhanced by introducing a new stiffness detection error control criterion. The new criterion avoids unnecessary reductions in the time step and minimizes the number of TLISMNI outer loop iterations required to achieve convergence. The TLISMNI method ensures that MBS algebraic constraint equations are satisfied at the position, velocity, and acceleration levels, efficiently exploits sparse matrix techniques, and avoids numerical force differentiation.

   A new procedure for smoothing the discontinuities at the FE interface was developed and tested using fluid problems. The new procedure is based on developing general curvature-continuity conditions that allow eliminating or minimizing discontinuity of the position gradients at the ANC element interface. Additionally, a new data-driven-science procedure for the analysis of geometry and recorded motion trajectories was introduced. The motion trajectories can be recorded experimentally or using computer simulations of detailed models. Differences between the time-invariant and motion-independent highway-road and railroad-track geometries and the time- and motion-dependent motion-trajectory geometries are identified using the new concept of Frenet angles.

    Several Ph.D. and M.S. students were involved in this research and were trained in the general area of computational and MBS dynamics. Several students who worked on this project are currently employed by the industry. The publication of the results (17 journal papers published or accepted plus two papers are currently under review) will contribute to disseminating the research results to other researchers, students, and engineers. The results of this research will aid in developing more reliable safety- and operation-guidelines for transportation systems, and will contribute to better understanding of the effect of sloshing on vehicle dynamics and to enhancing virtual prototyping algorithms used by the industry.

 


Last Modified: 09/01/2021
Modified by: Ahmed A Shabana
